timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText:
The expected behavior is,

when child node is removed, its subscribers get 'Removed' and its parent node (and all great parent node) subscribers get 'childRemoved' events.
when child node is changed, its subscribers get 'Changed' and its parent node (and all great parent node) subscribers get 'childChanged' events.

Leaf node only has changed/removed event. In the remove() function, parent node already sends 'childRemoved' information, so the function returns directly. Therefore I hardcode here to 'childChanged'. I can add more comment here.
